body:
Many urls these days throw ?ref=eib5p7tSeOo_23_0acaec6551517ed6e12302aff5ca34eib5p7tSeOo_23_0acaec6551517ed6e12302aff5ca34 after the necessary portion, so analytics can track from where people clicked through...but it also means that "they" are able to tell that when @kek posts an article about Human cloning that he used the same "ref" url that was posted on Stormfront 4 hours earlier...so that's where he found it.

Privacy-wise, it would be nice if we were able to just automatically trim anything with ?ref= in the url.
body_html:
Many urls these days throw ?ref=eib5p7tSeOo_23_0acaec6551517ed6e12302aff5ca34eib5p7tSeOo_23_0acaec6551517ed6e12302aff5ca34 after the necessary portion, so analytics can track from where people clicked through...but it also means that "they" are able to tell that when @kek posts an article about Human cloning that he used the same "ref" url that was posted on Stormfront 4 hours earlier...so that's where he found it.

Privacy-wise, it would be nice if we were able to just automatically trim anything with ?ref= in the url.

body: Some websites use query strings to determine what content to show you, so this would be tricky. It should be safe to trim common query strings used for tracking (utm, etc) if someone can dig up a list of those.
body_html: Some websites use query strings to determine what content to show you, so this would be tricky. It should be safe to trim common query strings used for tracking (utm, etc) if someone can dig up a list of those.

body:
This project strips out some common query strings, could steal their regex: https://github.com/jparise/chrome-utm-stripper

There's probably a more comprehensive list out there somewhere.
